Mexico City

One of the world's great capitals - 500 years of history, 150+ museums, and the best food scene in the Americas

Quick Facts About Mexico City

Best Time to Visit
March to May
Average Temperature
17°C (63°F) year-round
Known For
Museums, ancient ruins, world-class cuisine, art & culture
Airport Code
MEX

About Mexico City

Mexico City is the cultural heart of Mexico, home to over 150 museums, ancient Aztec ruins, UNESCO World Heritage sites, and what many consider the best food scene in the Western Hemisphere. This megacity of 21 million people offers world-class experiences at surprisingly affordable prices.

Built on the ruins of the ancient Aztec capital Tenochtitlan, Mexico City is a sprawling metropolis of over 21 million people that defies easy categorization. The historic center (Centro Histórico) showcases magnificent colonial buildings and the excavated Templo Mayor, while trendy neighborhoods like Roma, Condesa, and Coyoacán offer tree-lined streets, Art Deco architecture, and some of the best restaurants in Latin America. The city's cultural offerings are unmatched: the National Museum of Anthropology houses the world's finest collection of pre-Columbian artifacts, Frida Kahlo's Casa Azul provides intimate insight into the iconic artist's life, and the floating gardens of Xochimilco offer a glimpse of the city's pre-Hispanic past. From world-class galleries to underground speakeasies, from street taco stands to Michelin-starred restaurants, Mexico City delivers experiences that rival any global capital at a fraction of the cost. What makes CDMX truly special is how ancient and modern coexist seamlessly. You can start your morning at Aztec ruins, lunch at a cutting-edge contemporary restaurant, spend the afternoon in world-class museums, and end the evening in rooftop bars overlooking a city that never sleeps. This is a place where every neighborhood tells a different story, every meal is an adventure, and every visit reveals new layers of one of the world's most fascinating cities.

From luxury resorts to boutique hotels, find the perfect accommodation for your Mexico City vacation.

Where to Eat in Mexico City

Experience the best of Mexican cuisine and international dining in Mexico City.

  • Contemporary Mexican

    Pujol

    Chef Enrique Olvera's flagship, consistently ranked among the world's best restaurants. The tasting menu explores Mexico's culinary heritage with innovative techniques. Reservations essential, book months ahead.

    $$$$
  • Seafood

    Contramar

    Iconic seafood restaurant famous for its tuna tostadas and vibrant, buzzing atmosphere. A CDMX institution since 1998. No reservations - arrive early or queue.

    $$$
  • Contemporary Mexican

    Quintonil

    Chef Jorge Vallejo's elegant restaurant focusing on seasonal Mexican ingredients. Regularly ranked among the world's best. The tasting menu is a journey through Mexico's biodiversity.

    $$$$
  • Italian-Mexican

    Rosetta

    Chef Elena Reygadas's acclaimed Roma restaurant in a beautiful Art Nouveau mansion. Italian techniques with Mexican ingredients create something entirely unique.

    $$$
View all restaurants in Mexico City →

Neighborhoods in Mexico City

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Hipster paradise with stunning Art Nouveau and Art Deco buildings, tree-lined streets, world-class restaurants, and vibrant café culture. Roma Norte is the epicenter of CDMX's food renaissance.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Elegant neighborhood centered around two beautiful parks (Parque México and Parque España), known for its Art Deco buildings, outdoor cafés, and relaxed atmosphere.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Bohemian neighborhood with colonial-era architecture, charming plazas, and a village-like atmosphere. Home to Frida Kahlo's Casa Azul and the Leon Trotsky Museum.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Upscale neighborhood known for luxury shopping, high-end restaurants, and major museums including the National Museum of Anthropology and Museo Soumaya.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The UNESCO World Heritage historic heart of Mexico City, built over the Aztec capital. Home to the Zócalo, Metropolitan Cathedral, National Palace, and Templo Mayor ruins.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Leafy, upscale neighborhood with cobblestone streets, colonial mansions, and a famous Saturday artisan market (Bazar del Sábado).

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    UNESCO World Heritage city famous for Talavera pottery, the legendary mole poblano, and stunning colonial architecture including 70+ churches.

  • Mexico City

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Picturesque lakeside town popular with Mexico City residents for weekend escapes. Known for paragliding, sailing, and cobblestone streets.

Practical Information

Getting There

Mexico City International Airport (MEX) is Latin America's busiest airport with direct flights from major world cities. The new Felipe Ángeles International Airport (NLU) north of the city handles some international flights. From the airport, take Uber or authorized taxi to your hotel (30-60 minutes depending on traffic).

Getting Around

The metro is extensive and dirt cheap but crowded during rush hours. Uber and DiDi are the safest, most convenient options. Metrobús runs dedicated lanes on major corridors. Walking is pleasant in Roma, Condesa, Polanco, and Coyoacán. Avoid driving - traffic is brutal and parking difficult.

Safety Information

Stick to tourist-friendly neighborhoods (Roma, Condesa, Polanco, Centro Histórico during day, Coyoacán). Use Uber or DiDi instead of street taxis. Don't flash expensive jewelry or electronics. The metro is generally safe but watch for pickpockets during rush hour. Follow the same common-sense precautions you'd use in any major city.

Frequently Asked Questions About Mexico City

Is Mexico City safe for tourists?
Mexico City's main tourist areas like Roma, Condesa, Polanco, Coyoacán, and Centro Histórico are generally safe during the day. Use common sense: take registered taxis or Uber at night, avoid displaying expensive items, and stay aware of your surroundings. The metro is safe during the day but can be crowded. Millions of tourists visit safely each year.
How many days do you need in Mexico City?
Plan for at least 4-5 days to experience Mexico City's highlights, including major museums, the historic center, a day trip to Teotihuacán, and exploring different neighborhoods. Food lovers and culture enthusiasts could easily spend 7-10 days. Many travelers extend their stay once they experience the city's depth.
What is the best neighborhood to stay in Mexico City?
Roma and Condesa are the most popular for tourists, offering walkable streets, excellent restaurants, and a safe atmosphere. Polanco is upscale and convenient for museums. Centro Histórico puts you at the heart of history but is busier and louder. Coyoacán offers a quieter, more local experience.
Will I experience altitude sickness in Mexico City?
At 2,240 meters (7,350 feet), some visitors experience mild altitude effects like shortness of breath, headaches, or fatigue. Stay hydrated, avoid alcohol on arrival day, and take it easy for the first 24 hours. Most people adjust within a day or two. If coming from sea level, don't plan strenuous activities for your first day.
How do I get around Mexico City?
The metro is extensive, efficient, and cheap ($0.25 USD) but crowded during rush hours. Uber and DiDi are widely used, affordable, and safer than street taxis. The Metrobús is efficient for major corridors. Walking is pleasant in Roma, Condesa, and Coyoacán. Avoid driving yourself due to heavy traffic.
What is the best time to visit Mexico City?
March to May offers warm, dry weather before the rainy season. The rainy season (June-October) brings afternoon showers but mornings are usually clear. November-February is cooler and drier. December offers festive decorations, while Day of the Dead (late October/early November) is spectacular but busy.
Is the tap water safe to drink in Mexico City?
No, don't drink tap water. Bottled water is inexpensive and widely available. Restaurants and hotels use purified water for ice and cooking, so ice is generally safe. Stick to bottled or purified water to avoid any stomach issues.
Do I need to speak Spanish in Mexico City?
While Spanish is essential for local markets and smaller establishments, you can get by with English in tourist areas, upscale restaurants, and hotels. Learning basic Spanish phrases will greatly enhance your experience and is appreciated by locals. Download a translation app as backup.
What should I not miss in Mexico City?
Must-sees include the National Museum of Anthropology (half-day minimum), Zócalo and Centro Histórico, Teotihuacán pyramids, the Frida Kahlo Museum (book ahead), and exploring Roma/Condesa neighborhoods. Don't skip the food - from street tacos to world-class restaurants, eating is an essential part of the experience.
Is Mexico City expensive?
Mexico City offers incredible value compared to major world capitals. Street food costs $1-3, excellent restaurant meals $15-30, and even top restaurants are half the price of equivalents in New York or London. Budget travelers can explore comfortably on $50/day, while mid-range travelers might spend $100-150/day including hotels.
